question_feedback.student_choice: A bridge, because it stores and forwards all frames
question_feedback.correct_answer: A hub, because it creates a single collision domain where all devices compete for bandwidth
question_feedback.analysis: The student likely confused the store-and-forward mechanism of bridges/switches with the concept of bandwidth sharing. They may have thought that the store-and-forward process inherently causes delays that would slow down all network traffic.
question_feedback.explanation: A hub operates at the physical layer and creates a single collision domain where all connected devices share the total bandwidth. When one device transmits a large file, it consumes most of the available bandwidth, forcing other devices to wait. A bridge, while it does store and forward frames, creates separate collision domains and doesn't cause this type of bandwidth contention issue.

question_feedback.student_choice: A switch routes unknown frames while a hub bridges them
question_feedback.correct_answer: A switch floods unknown frames to all ports except the source, while a hub repeats all signals to all ports
question_feedback.analysis: The student confused the OSI layer functions and used incorrect terminology. They likely mixed up routing (Layer 3) with switching (Layer 2) operations, and misunderstood that hubs don't perform bridging functions.
question_feedback.explanation: Switches operate at Layer 2 and flood (not route) unknown unicast frames to all ports except the source port to learn MAC addresses. Hubs operate at Layer 1 and simply repeat electrical signals to all ports without any intelligence. Neither device 'routes' at Layer 2, and hubs don't perform bridging functions.
